title: Vanessa Sölter
subtitle: The personal portfolio of an Australian-based industrial designer
description: Vanessa Sölter is an Australian-based industrial designer who approached me after she wanted to convert her generic SquareSpace templated website into something a bit more unique and appropriate for someone calling themselves a designer. The site was rebuilt from the ground up by myself with plenty of input from Vanessa.

title: Steven Graaf
subtitle: The personal portfolio website of Steven de Graaf, a Dutch training advisor
description: Steven Graaf is a Netherlands-based training advisor who approached me for a very simple, static website he wanted built. Steven wanted a simple, to-the-point portfolio site that would outline who he was as a professional, and as such I stuck with a simple, vanilla HTML + CSS + Javascript stack, all hosted on Netlify.

title: Spotlight
subtitle: Keep track of your restaurant's online presence in one convenient spot!
description: Built with restaurant managers and owners in mind, Spotlight is a tool built with the intention of making their lives easier by taking away the monotony of having to check a huge number of different crowd-sourced review sites every single day. With Spotlight, all your Google, Tripadvisor, Zomato and Yelp reviews live under one unified dashboard for a much easier time accessing what your clients are thinking about.

title: AirP2P
subtitle: Rent out those games gathering dust and earn a quick buck
description: A Rails application built in a 1 week development sprint at the Le Wagon fullstack bootcamp. The pitch was that we wanted to create an "AirBNB Clone" as a proper introduction to the world of Rails development, and to also see how the 4 of us meshed in a team development setting. It was a lot of fun to work on it, and we're all pretty happy with the results.

title: Ember-Tac-Toe
subtitle: An online game of Tic-Tac-Toe played against a (dumb) computer
description: Ember-Tac-Toe was a project I had built as part of a coding interview challenge for a company called Feedback Fruits in 3 days. They were searching for Junior Fullstack devs, and had a great challenge in place where even developers unfamiliar with Ember like myself could get the chance to play around with it a bit and build out something fun and challenging.
The backend part of the stack is a Rails API hosted on Heroku that keeps a tally of a user's scores vs the naïve computer.

title: lu-ka.me
subtitle: My own site, the one you're currently on!
description: Perhaps it's unfair to list this as a project, it was, however, my first exposure to the Vue Framework, Nuxt. It's also one of the first websites I've ever seriously dedicated any kind of substantial time to, and it's seen a number of changes since its humble beginnings as 5 HTML files hastily stitched together by a complete beginner.
